channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rebuilding the Lighthouse of Alexandria, Block by Virtual Block
item.description: An ancient skyscraper considered the seventh wonder of the world crumbled to ruin centuries ago. Now an ambitious archaeological project aims to reassemble it in 3-D.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Florilegius/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A 19th-century engraved depiction of the Pharos of Alexandria.

item.title: At a Bonobo’s ‘Tea Party,’ Scientists Find Hints of Imagination
item.description: In a playtime experiment, researchers found that our closest living relatives have the capacity for make-believe, too.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: Rare Deep-Sea Giant Phantom Jellyfish Sighting Is Recorded on Video
item.description: During a dive off Argentina, scientists documented a rare jellyfish discovered a little over a century ago and seldom seen since, as well as the fish that keep it company.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: He Built a Server to Protect Indigenous Health Data
item.description: Joseph Yracheta was in charge of a repository that compiled and protected tribal health data. Then its funding was cut.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Tara Weston for The New York Times

item.title: NASA Eyes March Artemis II Launch After Hydrogen Leaks Delay Moon Mission
item.description: The agency did not complete a practice countdown for a flight that would be the first to send people around the moon in more than 50 years.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Artemis II rocket at the launch complex at Cape Canaveral, Fla. on Jan. 17.

item.title: Dozens of Earthquakes Have Rattled San Ramon, California
item.description: San Ramon, Calif., has been rattled by dozens of small earthquakes in recent months. Even in a region used to regular shaking, it’s been a lot.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times

item.title: What Do You Get When You Put a Mummy Through a CT Scan?
item.description: Experts are using high-res scanners and 3-D printers to illuminate ancient ailments and injuries.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner Nunn
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Summer Decker and her colleague Jonathan Ford used a 3-D printer to generate replicas of body parts and artifacts.

item.title: Snow Drought in the West Reaches Record Levels
item.description: Warm temperatures and extremely low snowfall threaten water resources for the year.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Jeff Bezos’s Rocket Company Blue Origin Pauses Space Tourism to Focus on the Moon
item.description: The New Shepard rocket from Blue Origin, which brought 92 people on trips to the edge of space, will cease flying for at least two years as the company prioritizes NASA contracts.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: TrumpRx: What to Know About Insurance Benefits, Pricing and Savings
item.description: People may be able to pay less for prescriptions with their insurance rather than via the new government website. The Trump drugstore is meant to help people buy medications using their own money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump; Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid; and Joe Gebbia, who oversees the design of government websites, unveiled TrumpRx at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building on Thursday.

item.title: Studying Antarctica’s Ice From the Side of a Helicopter
item.description: The fastest way into the gaps between gigantic blocks of a broken-up glacier is by lowering instruments from above, through the door of a helicopter.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Climate ‘Superfund’ Bills Spread Nationwide, Despite Legal Battles
item.description: The laws aim to force oil companies to help pay for damage from global warming. Industry is gearing up for state-by-state battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Flooding in Vermont in July 2023. The state was the first to adopt a climate “superfund” law. Other states are now following.

item.title: Federal Vaccine Advisers Take Aim at Covid Shots
item.description: One panelist accused the F.D.A. of withholding data on potential harms. The advisers also are reviewing research on vaccines given to pregnant women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Dr. Robert Malone, during a December meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices in Atlanta.

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Texas Law Targeting Critics of Fossil Fuels
item.description: The court ruled that it was unconstitutional to bar state agencies from investing with firms that the state had accused of boycotting the oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Trucks at an oil field in Midland, Texas. A judge ruled that a 2021 law about investing practices was unconstitutional.

item.title: F.D.A. Relaxes Rules on ‘Naturally Derived’ Dyes
item.description: Food makers will now be able to claim that their products have “no artificial colors,” so long as they use dyes that are not petroleum-based.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: “We’re asking people now, ‘Eat real food,’” Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said at the Tennessee State Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Nuclear Arms Control Era Comes to End Amid Global Rush for New Weapons
item.description: Beijing, Moscow and shaken American allies are seeking new warheads as President Trump ends more than a half century of nuclear arms control with Russia.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Alaska last year.

item.title: Senators Accuse Equifax of ‘Price-Gouging’ Medicaid Programs
item.description: The company’s data will be essential for many states to comply with new work requirements for the health insurance program that take effect next year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff, Margot Sanger-Katz and Asmaa Elkeurti
item.media:description: Many states rely on an Equifax product to verify Medicaid applicants’ wages and work hours.

item.title: Doctors’ Group Endorses Restrictions on Gender-Related Surgery for Minors
item.description: The A.M.A.’s announcement followed a similar recommendation from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Other medical groups argued for a more personalized approach.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health
item.media:description: Two major medical organizations have now endorsed age limits on gender-related surgery for teenagers struggling with gender dysphoria.

item.title: F.T.C. Settles With Express Scripts Over High Insulin Prices
item.description: The Trump administration announced that the company, a pharmacy benefit manager, had agreed to make significant changes to its practices.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Reed Abelson
item.media:credit: Sarah Holm/The Virginian-Pilot, via Associated Press
item.media:description: High insulin prices generated public outcry for years, though changes in the past few years have reduced patients’ costs to no more than $35 a month in most cases.

item.title: Trump Administration Is Delaying Hundreds of Wind and Solar Projects
item.description: Federal agencies are delaying approvals for renewable energy projects on both federal land and private property at a time when electricity demand is going up.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has been halting or delaying federal approvals that were once seen as routine.

item.title: A Chevron Refinery May Take in More Venezuelan Oil. Its Neighbors Are Concerned.
item.description: The American claim on Venezuela’s oil means even more of it could come to a huge Chevron refinery in Mississippi. Neighbors worried about pollution want the company to move them out.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Micah Green
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times

item.title: Congress Reins In Drug Middlemen in Effort to Lower Prescription Prices
item.description: The legislation will impose new restrictions on pharmacy benefit managers, giant companies like CVS Caremark, Optum Rx and Express Scripts that oversee prescription drug benefits.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Executives at the largest pharmacy benefit managers testified before a congressional committee in 2023.

item.title: Plastic Surgeons’ Group Advises Delaying Gender-Affirming Procedures Until Age 19
item.description: The organization’s latest guidance is a departure from the prevailing views of several other major medical organizations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: Between 2016 and 2020, about 3,700 patients 18 years old and younger have undergone gender transition surgery, mostly for breast removal, according to a JAMA study.

item.title: Woman Wins Malpractice Suit Over Gender Surgery as a Minor
item.description: In a legal first, a jury in New York awarded $2 million to a patient who said that doctors had deviated from accepted medical standards.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: Recent studies have suggested that between 5 and 10 percent of young people who had undergone gender-affirming care later decided to detransition.

item.title: The Questionable Science Behind the Odd-Looking Football Helmets
item.description: The N.F.L. claims Guardian Caps reduce the risk of concussions. The company that makes them says, “It has nothing to do with concussions.”
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: Jared Wilson, an offensive lineman for the Patriots, wore a Guardian Cap at the A.F.C. Championship game against the Broncos.

item.title: ‘Biblical Diseases’ Could Resurge in Africa, Health Officials Fear
item.description: Parasites and infections that cause blindness and other disabilities were nearly eliminated in some countries, but drug distribution to prevent and treat them was derailed in many places in 2025 after the U.S. cut aid.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times

item.title: Research Finds Interaction With Father, Not Mother, Affects Child Health
item.description: A long-term study of 292 families linked fathers’ parenting style to their children’s heart health years later. To researchers’ surprise, no such link was found with mothers.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

item.title: H.H.S. to Expand Faith-Based Addiction Programs for Homeless
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said addiction is a “spiritual disease” that calls out for the involvement of religious organizations.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, said the federal government would open funding opportunities to faith-based organizations that hold to evidence-based standards.

item.title: N.I.H. Worker Who Criticized Trump Seeks Whistle-Blower Protection
item.description: Jenna Norton, a National Institutes of Health employee, has been an outspoken critic of the administration’s research cuts and has been on paid leave.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:description: Jenna Norton last spring organized The Bethesda Declaration, a public letter that denounced what its authors viewed as the administration’s dismantling of the federal biomedical research apparatus.

item.title: Attempt to Drill Through Thwaites Glacier Is Foiled
item.description: Scientists lost their instruments within Antarctica’s most dangerously unstable glacier, though not before getting a glimpse at the warming waters underneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Threading a cable through the Thwaites glacier in an attempt to place monitoring equipment.

item.title: Judge Hands Trump a Fifth Loss in His Effort to Halt Offshore Wind Projects
item.description: The court ruled that construction can restart on a wind farm off the coast of New York State. The Trump administration had ordered work to stop in December.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Angus Mordant for The New York Times
item.media:description: A staging area for Orsted’s Sunrise Wind project at the Port of Coeymans south of Albany, N.Y., in 2024.

item.title: Psychosis Diagnoses Have Risen Among Young Canadians, Data Shows
item.description: Researchers believe increasing use of cannabis may be contributing to a rise in new cases of schizophrenia and related disorders at younger ages.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Chris Wattie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The study’s lead author said the results suggested an urgent need for more research into the impact of expanding use of cannabis by young people.

item.title: The Wonder Drug That’s Plaguing Sports
item.description: Ostarine held the promise of profound medical treatments. Something unexpected happened on the way to F.D.A. approval.
item.dc:creator: Jason Stallman

item.title: Rare Albatross Coasts Above California Waters Far From Home
item.description: The unexpected sighting of a waved albatross, which was thousands of miles from its typical range, earned it a label ornithologists reserve for the unexpected: an avian “vagrant.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Melody Baran/University of California-San Diego-Scripps Institution of Oceanography, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare waved albatross was spotted off the coast of Point Piedras Blancas, Calif., this month.

item.title: When the Doctor Needs a Checkup
item.description: The physician work force is aging fast, and some hospitals now require that older clinicians undergo testing for cognitive decline. Many have resisted.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: Morris Waxler, F.D.A. Official Who Switched Stance on Lasik, Dies at 88
item.description: While at the federal agency, he approved the laser device for eye surgery but later warned of its potential to cause harm.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: A Predictor of a Good Social Life? Your Parents.
item.description: A decades-long study suggested that close relationships with family members during teenage years could lead to a rich network of friendships in adulthood.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner Nunn
item.media:description: High social connection in adulthood was more than twice as common among people who had the strongest family ties in youth, compared with those who had the weakest.
